awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Finding Optimality in Practical Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to obtain provably optimal cryptographic constructions, using objectively practical techniques, for a wide range of tasks. To achieve this goal, the project makes progress on three technical fronts. First, a general-purpose framework is developed that encompasses and systematizes known practical cryptographic techniques from many domains. Second, the project develops techniques for  proving concrete, fine-grained lower bounds about constructions within this framework. Finally, techniques from program synthesis will be applied to the new framework. These techniques culminate in methods for automatically synthesizing secure and optimal cryptographic constructions.

This project focuses on cryptographic constructions that use fast, practical techniques. Such constructions are the most likely to have immediate impact on everyday use. The cryptographic applications areas being studied range from fundamental ones already in widespread use, such as symmetric-key encryption and digital signatures, to more advanced ones more recently approaching practical adoption like garbled circuits. The project also advances undergraduate and graduate education in cryptography with the ongoing development of comprehensive and innovative curricular materials.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the cryptographic properties of a special class of programs, called Linicrypt programs, and more broadly explored linear-algebraic perspectives in cryptography. A Linicrypt program is one in which all intermediate values are field elements, and the only allowed operations are to apply linear combinations to intermediate values and to invoke a random oracle with intermediate values (with the random oracle output also being a field element). This class of programs captures many practical techniques in cryptography, including block cipher modes, hash function constructions, hash-based signatures, and garbled circuits to name a few.

In this project we showed that Linicrypt programs can be represented algebraically, and that cryptographic properties of those programs can be characterized in terms of easily-checkable conditions on those algebraic representations. In particular, we showed how to symbolically determine: indistinguishability of two input-less Linicrypt programs, collision-resistance and second preimage resistance of a Linicrypt program, and output-pseudorandomness of randomized Linicrypt programs under adversarially chosen inputs. Thus, for a large and extremely useful class of cryptographic algorithms, it is possible to automatically and symbolically determine many of their useful cryptographic properties. We also explored methods for integrating these criteria into SAT solvers to synthesize Linicrypt programs -- that is, to find the "optimal" Linicrypt program subject to constraints on its correctness and security properties.

We also applied a linear-algebraic perspective to garbled circuit constructions, and crucially used that linear-algebraic perspective to develop several new and improved garbling techniques, including what is now the most efficient garbling scheme known to date.

In a related line of work, we studied the problem of private set intersection (PSI), where two or more parties hold a set of private items and want to learn which items are common to all sets, without revealing anything else about the contents of those sets. We developed new and improved protocol techniques which make PSI practical and scalable for large data sets. The new techniques effectively close the gap in performance between semi-honest and malicious security for PSI protocols.

Finally, the project has supported the PI's continuing effort to develop a free online cryptography curriculum (The Joy of Cryptography).
